conclusion: Analyze processes and apply thermodynamics to determine heat absorbed vs. released.
Cycle consists of two adiabatic and two isochoric processes.
Processes labeled: c→b (adiabatic compression), b→a (isochoric cooling), a→d (adiabatic expansion), d→c (isochoric heating).
In adiabatic processes, no heat exchange; work equals change in internal energy.
For adiabatic compression (c→b), work is done on the gas (W < 0).
For adiabatic expansion (a→d), work is done by the gas (W > 0).
In isochoric processes, volume constant, no work done.
In isochoric cooling (b→a), heat is released (Q < 0), decrease in internal energy.
In isochoric heating (d→c), heat is absorbed (Q > 0), increase in internal energy.
Net work done by gas is area enclosed by cycle in p-V diagram.
Area under adiabatic expansion (a→d) greater than under compression (c→b).
Net work done by gas (W_net) is positive.
First law: Net heat added (Q_net) equals net work done (W_net).
Total heat absorbed is greater than total heat released.
